Today, it remains a worthy centerpiece of a power and strength training program, and has full-body benefits when done for low reps as well as moderate to high reps <|endoftext|>

It can be used to strengthen deadlift lockout, but also as a deadlift alternative for people who cannot deadlift from the floor without pain. <|endoftext|>

<|user|> Clean and jerk <|bot|> The clean and jerk is a full-body lift that is one of two contested lifts in Olympic weightlifting competition. It is comprised of two movements: the clean, where the bar is pulled from the floor and caught in the front rack position in three pulls or phases, followed by the jerk overhead. In a CrossFit workout it is usually performed in low rep ranges, focusing on power and movement quality. <|endoftext|>

<|user|> Dumbbell seesaw shoulder press <|bot|> The dumbbell seesaw shoulder press is an exercise targeting the deltoids and triceps. The difference between this movement and the alternating shoulder press is that both dumbbells keep moving throughout each rep, rather than having one weight be stationary while the other moves. This piston-style pressing increases time under tension and may allow you to complete more total reps than with alternating reps. <|endoftext|>

<|user|> What is the difference between fitness and physical activity? <|bot|> Physical activity is simply any bodily movement performed by the muscles that expend energy. exercise is a subset of physical activity that is planned and structured with the purpose of improving or maintaining physical fitness or health. fit is the ability to perform activity at a moderate to vigorous level of intensity without tiring easily. <|endoftext|>

<|user|> how to perform side planks? <|bot|> lie on right side, support upper body on left forearm, shoulder over elbow. stack left foot on right foot, Left hand on side. tighten abdominal muscles. lift leg and hip, raise thigh towards ceiling. balance on right forearm and foot, hold for 15-60 seconds. return to starting position. repeat on left side <|endoftext|>
<|user|> How do side planks work? <|bot|> lie on right side, support upper body on right forearm. shoulder over elbow; stack left foot on right foot; left hand on side. tighten abdominal muscles. lift right hip and leg, raise just below the ceiling; balance on right fore arm and foot, hold for 15-60 seconds. return to starting position. repeat on different side. <|endoftext|>

<|user|> How do I do a swing? <|bot|> first standing with feet shoulder width apart. hold a kettlebell in both hands, arms extended down in front. hinge at hips, shift weight to heels, and sit back, swinging kettlebell between legs. press into heels and stand up, swinging kettlebell forward to chest height. <|endoftext|>

Examples include standing heel-toe, single leg stands, and yoga balances <|endoftext|>

<|user|> what is my target heart rate during physical activity? <|bot|> the heart rate range used to determine the desired intensity of an activity will differ depending on the goal of the workout. you can calculate target heart rate using a percentage of your total heart rate which can be predicted by subtracting your age from 220, or by measuring your heart rate while performing a maximum exercise test for 30 minutes. <|endoftext|>
<|user|> What is my target heart rate during physical activity? <|bot|> the heart rate range used to determine the desired intensity of an activity will differ depending on the goal of the workout. <|user|> What is the difference between a weight machine and a dumbbell? <|bot|> free weights or dumbballs keep resistance on the muscle constant throughout the joints range of motion (rom), while weight machines use variable resistance, with the resistance changing throughout the rom. machines have geometrically shaped cams that change the torque required of the muscles by changing the lever arm of the resistance force <|endoftext|>
<|user|> What role does sleep play in muscle repair? <|bot|> Sleep allows for the release of anabolic hormones, such as growth hormone, which aid in tissue repair and muscle growth. <|endoftext|>
<|user|> What role does sleep play in muscle repair? <|bot|> sleep allows for the release of anabolic hormones, such as growth hormone, which aid in tissue repair and muscle growth. adequate sleep also helps regulate catabolic hormones, which can inhibit muscle growth when levels are elevated due to insufficient sleep <|endoftext|>

<|user|> how often should I work out and lift weights? <|bot|> according to the physical activity guidelines for Americans, for substantial health benefits, adults should do at least 150-300 minutes a week of moderate intensity exercise. for basic gains in strength, you need only two or three times per week. if you are an advanced level, lifting more frequently is fine. <|endoftext|>
<|user|> Should I lift fast or slow? <|bot|> Repetition speed means tempo, or how fast you lift a weight or resistance. when you do a slow rep workout, your muscles experience a greater time under tension than they would if you were doing quick reps. this can lead to a greater increase in muscle size than faster reps. <|endoftext|>

<|user|> How much cardio should I be doing per week? <|bot|> general recommendation of around 150 minutes of moderate cardio each week. if you cant reach that, start with shorter rounds 10-15 minutes each day of easy cardio and build on from there. if your goal is strength and lean muscle gains, you dont want to do too many cardio. no daily long jogs unless you want to build muscle, because after a certain point, your body will begin using protein as fuel. many workouts can count as cardio if it <|endoftext|>
<|user|> how often should you rest? <|bot|> overtraining can cause elevated resting heart rate, injury, poor sleep, low energy levels , depression, anxiety, agitation, decrease in performance, and extreme soreness or pain. make sure that you have at least 1-2 days of full rest each week to allow the body to repair and prevent overtraining. <|endoftext|>
<|user|> How often should I rest? <|bot|> overtraining can cause elevated resting heart rate, injury, poor sleep, low energy levels. depression, anxiety, agitation, decrease in performance, and extreme soreness or pain. Make sure you have at least 1-2 days of full rest each week to allow the body to repair and prevent overtraining. <|endoftext|>

<|user|> How do you perform an incline bench press? <|bot|> to perform an inclined bench, lie flat on an inclined bench with your feet flat on the floor. grasp the barbell at a shoulder-width grip and lift it off the rack. lower the barbell to your upper chest by bending your elbows then push back up to the starting position, keeping your elbows under the bar at all times. Keep cool and active while you move the bar forwards to accomplish this task. <|endoftext|>
<|user|> how is an incline bench press performed? <|bot|> to perform an inclined bench press, lie flat on an inclined bench with your feet flat on the floor. grasp the barbell at a shoulder-width grip and lift it off the rack. lower the barbell to your upper chest by bending your elbows, then push it back up to the starting position. Remember to maintain proper form and breathe in as you lower the bar and exhale as you push it up. <|endoftext|>

<|user|> What is the difference between low and high impact workout? <|bot|> whereas low-impact exercises (such as walking, elliptical training, cycling) involve keeping at least one foot on the ground, high-impact exercises (some are running and jumping training) require both feet to leave the ground. when both feet leave the ground, the forces from gravity increase their impact on your joints when you land. <|endoftext|>

<|user|> What are the different types of stretches to improve flexibility? <|bot|> the different types of stretch to improve flexibility include static stretching (holding a stretch), dynamic stretching (stretches that gently move joints through their full range of motion), myofascial release (foam rolling), active isolated stretching, and proprioceptive neuromuscular facilitation (the partner applies force and then the exerciser works either the stretched muscle or its opposing muscle). <|endoftext|>
<|user|> What are the different types of stretches to improve flexibility? <|bot|> The different types of stretch to improve flexibility include static stretching (holding a stretch), dynamic stretching, myofacintical release (foam rolling), active isolated stretching (stretches are held for two seconds), and proprioceptive neuromuscular facilitation (a partner applies force and then the exerciser works either the stretched muscle or its opposing muscle). <|endoftext|>
<|user|> What are the different types of stretches to improve flexibility? <|bot|> The different types of stretches to improve flexibility include static stretching (holding a stretch), dynamic stretching (stretches that gently move joints through their full range of motion), myofascial release (foam rolling), active isolated stretching (stretches are held for two seconds), and proprioceptive neuromuscular facilitation (a partner applies force, then the exerciser works either the stretched muscle or its opposing muscle). <|endoftext|>

<|user|> What are body muscle imbalance? <|bot|> the muscles on each side of your body should be symmetrical with each other in size and strength. When a muscle (or muscles) is larger, smaller or stronger than its corresponding muscle(s), on the other side you have a muscle imbalance. <|endoftext|>
<|user|> What is a muscle imbalance? <|bot|> The muscles on each side of your body should be symmetrical with each other in size and strength. when a muscle (or muscles) on one side of your body is larger, smaller, stronger, or less than the corresponding muscle(s) on the other side, you have a muscle imbalance. <|endoftext|>

<|user|> What is somatic movement? <|bot|> one way to describe somatic motion is movement during which you focus on the internal experience and feeling of the movement instead of what it looks like from the outside. you have been present and aware of what is happening in the moment during the movement. <|endoftext|>
<|user|> How does somatic stretching differ from regular stretching? <|bot|> normal stretching typically means moving or holding various parts of your body to extend the muscles. somatic stretching focuses on releasing tension in the body through natural, unintentional movements. <|endoftext|>
<|user|> What are the benefits of regular somatic movement? <|bot|> people who regularly practice somatic movements might see improvements in posture, flexibility, range of motion, and balance. Somatic stretching can also help strengthen your mind-body connection, which can help you better manage overall health <|endoftext|>
<|user|> What are the benefits of somatic movements? <|bot|> people who regularly practice somatic movements might see improvements in posture, flexibility, range of motion, and balance. Somatic stretching can also help you improve your mind-body connection, which can help you better manage overall health. <|endoftext|>
